labels.name: editorial
labels.description: A matter that the editors can dispose of without working group consensus

issues.title: Search and Discovery
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: Discussed in the Brussels meeting - there was broad agreement in the room that because search and discovery are often intertwined with AI, and because robots.txt also implicates search and discovery, it is important to attempt to address these use cases in our vocabulary.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Discussed at the design team meeting and this was pretty uncontroversial.  There is some text in #66 that adds some context.

issues.title: Inference-time preferences
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: Discussed in the Brussels meeting -- there was broad support for also defining at least one vocabulary term for inference-time use of content by models. More than one term may be necessary, but the sense of the room was that we should keep this as simple as possible at the first instance.

comments.author: BradSilver99
comments.body: Are there inference-time uses beyond RAG that others think we should include?  As was expressed in Brussels, the scraping of content for use in summarizing/synthesizing responses to user queries (i.e. at inference time) was a core concern for publishers - which is what we would currently refer to as accomplished via RAG.  I believe this should be the focus.

comments.author: bquinn
comments.body:
> Are there inference-time uses beyond RAG that others think we should include? As was expressed in Brussels, the scraping of content for use in summarizing/synthesizing responses to user queries (i.e. at inference time) was a core concern for publishers - which is what we would currently refer to as accomplished via RAG. I believe this should be the focus.

If we go with an embedded metadata use case for our work, then the "upload an image at inference time" use case applies. Someone may embed metadata into a media object that says "this media should not be used for inference without my permission" etc.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
Something that came up during discussion was that training sometimes involves inference.  We might want to define (generative) AI inference as specifically excluding use as a part of AI training, because the AI training category would subsume the inference part.

Edit: We might already have that with our parenthetical in the definition: "(as opposed to the training of the model)".  Thanks @bquinn for pointing that out.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Another thing that came up is that people might offer inputs to a model and expect to override the preferences that are attached to those inputs.  We should explicitly acknowledge that use case and note that people can (and will) provide inputs and override stated preferences.

comments.author: lrosenthol
comments.body: As I noted in the meeting, the original use case for inference comes from the ability for users to add a "sample" to a prompt where the user can then say "like that".   This is especially important for situations like the [Studio Ghibli concerns](https://apnews.com/article/studio-ghibli-chatgpt-images-hayao-miyazaki-openai-0f4cb487ec3042dd5b43ad47879b91f4) that came up recently.

comments.author: bquinn
comments.body:
> As I noted in the meeting, the original use case for inference comes from the ability for users to add a "sample" to a prompt where the user can then say "like that". This is especially important for situations like the [Studio Ghibli concerns](https://apnews.com/article/studio-ghibli-chatgpt-images-hayao-miyazaki-openai-0f4cb487ec3042dd5b43ad47879b91f4) that came up recently.

There are many similar use cases. Another is that someone may "AI-launder" copyrighted content: they could upload a copyrighted image to a gen-AI engine and give a prompt to make a very minor change, and then distribute the resulting image, claiming "it's an AI-generated image, so it's uncopyrightable".

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
This is something that is most acute with inference as it is the area in which people are most likely to want to do that sort of referencing/grounding/input.  For instance, taking written text and asking for a summary.

Something @lrosenthol said during the meeting seemed right to me.  We can have the definition include prohibitions (or reservations, or the opposite) for inferences of all those types, but then leave the question as to whether different parts of the system respect that to the people who are building those elements.  And their lawyers.

One possible response is to respect opt-outs and refuse to process inputs.  For instance, it could be that copying of style is not something that a particular product wants to be associated with.

Another approach is to ask the user of the system to accept the responsibility for contravening expressed preferences.  That might manifest in a number of ways from implicit/invisible (terms of service that make users responsible for respecting preferences for the content they source) to very prominent (an active prompt when using content that has preferences not to allow inference that forces users to accept that).

RAG systems where automated systems seek out and ingest content probably have a different set of constraints on what they can or cannot do.  Still, the suite of options available for people building those products are still roughly along the same lines.

Either way, this is not necessarily something that we have to decide here.  It's worth understanding, for sure, so that we are sure that the set of possibilities we enable are acceptable.  I am personally comfortable with that.

comments.author: paul2keller
comments.body:
To me, it is pretty clear that at this stage, we have two lines of argument related to the question of how we can prevent preferences about inference from impacting individual users’ rights, that we will need to resolve at some point (in London, I assume).

1) The first one goes for a broad definition of inference (use of an asset as input for a trained model) and assumes that the protection of users’ rights can best be left to implementers / the market (if a tool interprets preference signals very restrictively, then just use another tool that does not). This also leans on the understanding that preferences are just preferences and can be deliberately ignored by developers/deployers of tools/systems.

2) The second one goes for a more narrow definition (probably more accurately described as RAG) where the preference only applies to assets that are autonomously retrieved by an AI system as input for its operation. This would exclude uses that are initiated by the user and thus have a more limited impact on users’ rights.

Does this distinction make sense?

comments.author: felixreda
comments.body:
Hi Paul,

This distinction makes sense and it is indeed a good topic for discussion on the vocabulary in London.

I am convinced that the market won’t be able to solve the user rights issue, because secondary legislation is already pointing towards technical standards as an enforcement mechanism for copyright enforcement. Under the EU AI Act, AI model developers will mostly demonstrate compliance by signing up to a Code of Practice, which is currently being finalized. The latest draft version of the Code of Practice requires AI developers to: 

"(a) employ web-crawlers that read and follow instructions expressed in accordance with the
Robot Exclusion Protocol (robots.txt), as specified in the Internet Engineering Task Force
(IETF) Request for Comments No. 9309, and any subsequent version of this IETF standard,
and
(b) make best efforts to identify and comply with other appropriate machine-readable protocols
to express rights reservations pursuant to Article 4(3) of Directive (EU) 2019/790, for
example through asset-based or location-based metadata“

In other words, while the preference signals are voluntary, they may very well end up having a quasi-mandatory effect on AI developers through the AI Act Code of Practice. Users won’t have the option to simply switch to another provider if the vocabulary requires AI companies that want to „read and follow“ or „identify and comply with" the preference signals to restrict actions of their users that are perfectly legal under copyright law.

That’s why it is very important, if we don’t want the preference signals to inadvertently become a mechanism for technologically depriving end users of their rights under copyright law (such as the right to private copying, parody etc.), the vocabulary has to define the actions of end users interacting with AI tools as out of scope.

Best,
Felix

> Am 25.06.2025 um 12:23 schrieb Paul Keller ***@***.***>:
> 
> To me, it is pretty clear that at this stage, we have two lines of argument related to the question of how we can prevent preferences about inference from impacting individual users’ rights, that we will need to resolve at some point (in London, I assume).
> 
> The first one goes for a broad definition of inference (use of an asset as input for a trained model) and assumes that the protection of users’ rights can best be left to implementers / the market (if a tool interprets preference signals very restrictively, then just use another tool that does not). This also leans on the understanding that preferences are just preferences and can be deliberately ignored by developers/deployers of tools/systems.
> 
> The second one goes for a more narrow definition (probably more accurately described as RAG) where the preference online applies to assets that are autonomously retrieved by an AI system as input for its operation. This would exclude uses that are initiated by the user and thus have a more limited impact on users’ rights.
> 
> Does this distinction make sense?
> 
> —

>

comments.author: lrosenthol
comments.body: Looking forward to discussing this further @felixreda as while I understand where you are coming from, you also need to understand where the Creative community is coming from and their desires - which are just as valid.

comments.author: BradSilver99
comments.body: @felixreda I know you use the word "quasi" to qualify "mandatory" here, but since the Code of Practice is voluntary (and we are still awaiting its final form) I am not sure the word mandatory could apply here, even in a "quasi" form.    I do think the argument for not trying to solve for this its purest form is that we are enabling preferences.  The example about the Code of Practice indicates that governments (not this group) can and will do whatever they want to shape rules which govern the use of content - and I think it is in those forums that these discussions should happen to address concerns about how far those rules go.  I don't think we should curtail preferences because of what governments might do in the future.

comments.author: llemeurfr
comments.body:
In this discussion, there are clearly two variants of "inference". 

In the first variant, the content that may be flagged with an opt-out is provided by a user as part of a REQUEST to an AI system. As already mentioned in this thread, preventing users from feeding an AI system with this content may violate their rights, particularly in relation to accessibility needs. I'll take as examples the request for an image description or the simplification of a complex paragraph for somebody with an intellectual disability. 

It is true that in this first variant, a user providing a document to an AI system and prompting "copy it with a few differences" is going against the will of the content owner. However, I imagine that anti-parasitism and anti-counterfeit laws would apply if he publicly releases the results of this process. 

I'm therefore not comfortable with an AI preference that can easily clash with accessibility requirements (especially if some system developers poorly understand the nuance). 

In the second variant, the content possibly flagged with an opt-out is provided by the system as part of the RESPONSE offered by the AI system. This is typically the RAG case, where fresh content is combined with a trained model to improve the response. The AI system is responsible for the content it selects, there is no clash with pro-accessibility laws, and the AI preferences are therefore easy to apply. 

Nobody knows how long the term RAG will survive before a new method appears. But isn't there a term sitting conceptually between "inference" and "RAG" that we could adopt for this vocabulary?

issues.title: TDM
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: Discussed in the Brussels meeting. There was some question of whether it was necessary to define a broad TDM term in the vocabulary, but there was not agreement about removing it.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: General view from the design team was that the definition is good.  The only reservation was the name, for which we are open to taking suggestions, but are looking for something along the lines of "automated processing", "computational analysis", etc...

comments.author: paul2keller
comments.body: I think we can close this one, name has been changed to “Automated Processing”

issues.title: Eurocentricity
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: The draft is currently written in a Europe-specific way.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: I believe that the present text is better.  We only have a hanging reference to the EU TDM legislation, that we might need to remove.

comments.author: paul2keller
comments.body: I agree and I think we can remove that reference, seems like the proposal for keeping the TDM language largely as is was well received on the mailing list (that is my positive way of interpreting the lack of responses).

comments.author: paul2keller
comments.body: I believe that this can be closed once we have also removed the informative reference to the CDSM directive at the top (See #89).

issues.title: Hierarchy
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: The proposed vocabulary has nesting / hierarchy - use of one term can imply the use of another. In the Brussels meeting, we discussed that this may not always prove to be the case, but no conclusions were reached.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: After discussion at the design team meeting, the direction we have is that the arrangement is solid.

issues.title: AI Definition
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: Discussed in the Brussels meeting - the definition of terms like 'AI' need to be examined and potentially refined.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: We've discussed and proposed new names for the categories of use and I have added definitions for AI and training in #93.

issues.title: Mapping vocabulary to preferences
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: Discussed in the Brussels meeting. The vocabulary is abstract; it defines terms (e.g., "X") but does not define how to declare preferences (e.g., "I do not prefer X").

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: This is dealt with, at least in part, by #25.  We'll keep iterating and check in once that is done.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Closing this for now.  We do need to have another editorial pass, but the bones are in the document(s).

issues.title: Vocabulary interface to preferences
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
Discussed in the Brussels meeting. The vocabulary (even when mapped to preferences; see #7) does not specify how an attachment mechanism should express it. 

Sense of the room in Brussels was that:
* The vocabulary should define an abstract model
* The vocabulary should also define a preferred / recommended mapping to strings (i.e., a serialisation)
* Individual attachment mechanisms can opt into using that serialisation, or may define their own

issues.title: "Good" uses
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
E.g., spam filtering, identifying offensive language

Sense in Brussels was that this would be covered by the legal regime, not vocabulary.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: Discussed in London/Madrid; closing absent more input.

issues.title: "Bad" uses
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
E.g., weapons, biometrics, other uses that content owners may not want to countenance. 

Sense in Brussels was that we will not address this in the first deliverables, but might consider in future extensions.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Closing this issue for the moment.  No one has proposed anything along these lines.  Obviously, that doesn't preclude the expansion of the set of usage categories in future, just for the first version.

issues.title: Time preferences are applied
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: Content might be gathered a long time before it is used. Which location-based attachment should apply to such content -- that requested at approximately the same time as the content, or the most current document?

comments.author: lrosenthol
comments.body:
this is an excellent question - which goes into all sorts of directions when one considered the "validity lifetime" of such declarations, and also the places from which the assets were obtained.

For example, if the source no longer exists (i.e., 404), if the TLS cert for the site has expired, etc.

issues.title: Identifying the set of relevant attachment mechanisms
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
The architecture we're developing accommodates attachment mechanisms that we define in our "core" documents, as well as future extensions -- including those defined by us and by third parties.

Content providers need to know which attachment mechanisms will be paid attention to, and consumers of preferences need to know which ones they're supposed to check. 

There might be:

* one canonical list (e.g., in our specification or an IANA registry)
* more than one list (e.g., defined per-use-case, such as for crawling-to-train vs inference-time)
* undefined list (e.g., defined by legal authority)

comments.author: lrosenthol
comments.body: I would also think that there are two primary categories of attachment - location-based & unit/asset-based - and how that aspect is expressed

comments.author: lrosenthol
comments.body:
But I agree that for this particular document, we need only address a specific set of attachments.  REP and HTTP headers seem like the right set.

That said, we should have some text in the document that mentions the existence of other methods (but we need not include specific links)

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
What we currently have [here](https://ietf-wg-aipref.github.io/drafts/draft-ietf-aipref-attach.html#section-1.3):

> This document does not define a means of embedding preferences in content. Embedding preferences is expected to be an effective means of associating preferences with content, because it ensures that metadata is always associated with content.
>
> The main challenge with embedding is that a different method is needed for each content type. That is, a different means of conveying preferences needs to be defined for each audio, documents, images, video, or other content format. Furthermore, some content types, such as plain text (text/plain), offer no universal means of carrying metadata. Though preferences might still be embedded in content with these formats, those preferences would not be reliably accessible to an automated system.

comments.author: lrosenthol
comments.body: Submitted #57 to improve that paragraph

issues.title: Combination
issues.author: mnot
issues.body:
In Brussels, a sense emerged that we would only address combination for different preferences for the same content (e.g., robots.txt and HTTP header applied to the same file). We would not address combination of preferences from different sources (e.g., the same image from two different sites).

This should be documented in the applicability statement. We also need to determine the algorithm, e.g.,

* Most restrictive
* Most specific attachment
* Most specific preference

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
We have an issue regarding specificity and whether "nesting" is a desirable thing (#5).  If we resolve that, then the logical thing to do is ensure that only the most-specific preference applies.

Setting that aside, we still need to resolve the question of how to resolve conflicting preferences for the same thing.  I heard that most restrictive was perhaps the safest approach, but there are some potential secondary information channels that might lead to weighting things differently.  For instance, an HTTP header field might be considered as an override for something in robots.txt rather than having both preferences apply.

Things to consider also are the specificity associated with different channels.  If both HTTP header field and robots.txt apply and we go with most specific, most restrictive (in that order) then a more specific "allow" statement in robots.txt would override a less specific "deny" statement in the header field.  That might be surprising to the entity specifying the "deny" preference.  Either is potentially acceptable, but we need to be very clear about what the properties of the system are, especially for cases like this.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: @mnot, I notice that you flagged this as being for an applicability statement.  I suspect that we will want to have some sort of rules for processing in the core vocabulary draft.  The less those are definitive, the more we'll end up relying on things like applicability statements.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: Yep - it's flagged both for that and for the combination bit (which per Brussels discussion is likely to end up in the vocab document).

issues.title: Applicability Statement
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: This issue captures potential items to discuss in an applicability statement intended for regulators and other parties using the framework we define.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body:
- opt-in vs opt-out
- robots time dimension
- disparate assertions from multiple sources
- hosted content
- rightsholder identification
- accessibility, academic / research / spam filters, impact upon other "good" uses
- data protection / privacy
- enforcement / audit
- bot identification / authentication
- TDM is very broad

issues.title: Opt-in / Opt-out
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: The “opt-out” framing needs to be replaced by a preferences framing, without bias to opt-out or opt-in.

issues.title: Move AI intent to the top
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
Regarding the statement of what the document is intended to address (AI training first, generic automated processing second, I think):

> I would move this to the top, since this, IMO is a KEY PART of this work!

_Originally posted by @lrosenthol in https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/pull/17#discussion_r2071478546_

issues.title: How can prior preferences be updated?
issues.author: gitnnelg
issues.body:
How can preferences previously specified for an asset be updated?

Could an Expires After label be applied in a AI Preferences file?

Could a URL be provided that identifies that the location of the current preferences be specified?

Is there a means for a publisher of a preference to label a prior preference as expired?

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: Closing until it's raised and discussed on list.

issues.title: How to express preferences for multi-element media ?
issues.author: gitnnelg
issues.body:
How shall preferences in the vocabulary distinguish between media elements in multi-element media?

A few cases that can be built into more complete cases:

1. Media with 1 -Video element and 2-single audio track
2. Images with 1-Picture element and 2-A descriptive element
3. Media with 1-Video element, 2-single audio element, 3-closed caption/description element
4. Media with 1-video, and 2a,b,c...N   distinct audio elements 


In all the above examples, who would different preference expressions be expressed in the vocabulary?

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
That's a question for attachment mechanisms.  If content is delivered over HTTP, then we have either robots.txt or headers that can only describe preferences for resources or representations.  If something is comprised of multiple components, those will be unable to target specific components unless they are exposed as discrete HTTP resources.

If this use case is important to you, then I'd suggest that you need to define a more complex attachment method specific to the media container.  None of the attachment methods we've talked about thus far are capable of that sort of finer-grained targeting.

comments.author: gitnnelg
comments.body:
it may well be that for complex media types that a specialized attachment mechanism is required. 

The current focus is on vocabulary, so it is not unreasonable to consider including a media element distinguishing ability in the vocabulary which then would enable binding mechanisms to use the vocabulary element in their binding.

while it's very likely some binding mechanism will be able to distinctly bind different preferences to individual media elements,   the container approach to bundling media elements so that they can be transmitted as a single container is commonly used.    

So even in the HTTP example, when a container of multiple-media elements is the discrete asset at the HTTP level, there would be usefulness in being able to express different preferences for the elements in the container.    Typically these will be an expression of different preferences for Video than for Audio, especially when the audio element may consist of spoken words and of music.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: Closing until it's raised and discussed on list.

issues.title: Territory expression?
issues.author: gitnnelg
issues.body:
How can territory be expressed in the vocabulary?

Preference setting may want to express something like:

In the US the preferrences are:   .....
In the UK the preferences are:    ....
The default preferences, unless a more specific policy is provided are: ....

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
I don't see this as a necessary extension.  That is, because it is possible for a server to adapt content to the requester.  For instance, look at the incoming (apparent) geolocation and send different preferences according to that.

That's far less complicated for a consumer and it means that the producer doesn't have to reveal the entirety of their preferences/policy to each requester.

comments.author: gitnnelg
comments.body:
Crawler location identification can be problematic at request time.     This could be because (1) the geo-location of the crawler ASN/IP is not accurate   (2) the crawler is operating out of multiple ASN/IP to load balance its access. (3) the crawler is in territory A, but the preferences will be applied in territory B.

So would seem that there would be usefulness in having the option to express preferences to be applied by territory so that the complete set could be communicated as a whole

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: I just don't see this as being sufficiently useful.  I would rather advise people to say "no" and give them a way to do more in-depth negotiation of terms of use.  Outside of any machine-readable format.  Yes, that means lawyers.  And no, I don't see that as a problem.  We've got more than enough complexity for our machine-readable solution without adding geopolitics selectors to the pile.

comments.author: bquinn
comments.body:
FYI, the TDMRep protocol has some work in this area. They effectively define three states that can be declared by rights holders:

1. "yes you can scrape"
2. no you can't scrape" and
3. "you can scrape only under the conditions specified in the accompanying metadata field".

Option 3 can then refer to an ODRL policy which can specify any number of restrictions including territory and others.

We at IPTC have created some tools to make creating these policies easier: [RightsML/ODRL generator](https://iptc.org/std/RightsML/generator/) and [simplerights.iptc.org](https://simplerights.iptc.org/).

But parsing ODRL is not trivial, so we fully expect most bots/AI providers to treat "you can only scrape if..." as equivalent to "no".

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: Closing until it's raised and discussed on list.

issues.title: Is "asset" the right label?
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
In looking at this, the term "asset" might be assumed to imply ownership, such that preferences can only be expressed by entities that "own" the affected content.

Can we instead use the more neutral term "content"?  Or, minimally, something that is less prejudicial about the arrangement between the entity that expresses a preference and the subject that is covered.

comments.author: paul2keller
comments.body: I think the use of the term "asset" is fine in this context. To me it does not really imply ownership. if it implies something than this is value, wich feels appropriate. Also the proposed alternative "content" is something that many people on the rightholder side dislike (partially, because they feel it devalues creative expression).

comments.author: lrosenthol
comments.body: The other reason that many folks prefer *asset* over *content*, is that to many contents refers only to the human consumable parts (e.g., pixels, video, text, etc.) but does **not** include the machine readable elements (e.g., metadata).   Asset, however, apply to the whole thing.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Was the term "artifact" ever suggested?  That doesn't carry the strong implication of being owned. It might carry an implication of age, but not as strongly.

comments.author: lrosenthol
comments.body:
>Was the term "artifact" ever suggested? That doesn't carry the strong implication of being owned. It might carry an implication of age, but not as strongly.

Artifact is problematic because it has the connotation of being "secondary" or at least not the primary thing.

comments.author: bnewbold
comments.body:
"Asset" also reads to me as implying property or formal legal ownership, especially pertaining to exclusion and monetary value, and does not seem like the best terminology to use in these documents covering any form of transferred data.

@lrosenthol I don't agree that "asset" is more inclusive of metadata (in addition to a primary work) compared to "content" or "artifact". And I would agree that "artifact" might imply a specific representation as opposed to an abstract work, but I think that is potentially a more correct connotation in the case of digital objects (which are always representations).

Pulling the current VOCAB abstract in-line as context:

> This document proposes a standardized vocabulary for expressing preferences related to how digital assets are used by automated processing systems. This vocabulary allows for the creation of structured declarations about restrictions or permissions for use of digital assets by such systems.

"Content" does like a straight-forward term to use here. HTTP already uses the term in places like the `Content-Type` header, and the ATTACH draft already uses it in the title ("Indicating Preferences Regarding *Content* Usage").

Another common term in the web context is "Resource".

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
> And I would agree that "artifact" might imply a specific representation as opposed to an abstract work, but I think that is potentially a more correct connotation in the case of digital objects (which are always representations).

For digital *things*, though there might be a platonic ideal or original, this doesn't have any bearing on what we're saying here.  A *thing* that is reproduced from an original (a digital scan of the Mona Lisa, say) is no different from an image that was wholly digital at its inception.  The subject of the preference is the sequence of bits, maybe with its metadata.

I don't agree with Leonard that "artifact" implies secondary.  From my visits to museums, the use of the word in that context seems pretty clearly applicable to primary instances.  But then, perhaps all digital things being secondary is something we can embrace, rather than consider to be a failing of sorts.  That there can be no "primary" instance is a delightful idea to me.

> the ATTACH draft already uses it in the title

I would not consider that as a reason to use "Content".  Though I do regard it positively, despite the negative connotations.  To Paul's point, In my industry "user" has negative connotations as it can have a dehumanizing impact; it's still a term of art though.  You might say the same for "consumer" in economics or "patient" in a medical setting.

comments.author: felixreda
comments.body: I think "resource" is a good suggestion. It doesn't seem to suffer from any of the pitfalls that have been identified in this thread.

comments.author: paul2keller
comments.body: "ressource" also works for me although I still prefer "asset" because it implies that we are talking about things that are valued.

comments.author: lrosenthol
comments.body: Given the context of the web/http and its use of resource, I have no objection to that term either.   And then in related docs (e.g., CAWG) we can map resource->asset.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
Given use in HTTP, this has some potential for confusion.  In HTTP, a "resource" refers to the thing at the other end of a URL.  A "representation" is the bits that might be exchanged when interacting with a resource.

Not saying that this is a deal-breaker, but it will be confusing.

comments.author: paul2keller
comments.body: it just shows that "asset" makes more sense 😄 (representation raises the question of "representation of what?")

comments.author: chrisn
comments.body: I agree that asset makes more sense. I think we should the potential for confusion with HTTP (and indeed not tie the vocabulary to HTTP semantics).

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Thanks everyone.  I'm happy to be wrong in this case.

issues.title: Extensibility
issues.author: mnot
issues.body: The vocabulary should be able to evolve.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
This includes the question of how - if needed - we extend the vocabulary.  There is some of what is necessary in #26 about this, but that isn't complete.  For instance, on-list discussion seems to be moving toward the idea of having an IANA registry for the vocabulary.  If that holds, we'll need to add something for that.

Then there are extensions that are not limited to the vocabulary.  If we go with #26, that might be non-vocabulary dictionary keys or parameters on those keys (which might be specific to different vocabulary terms).

My proposal is to define clearly how to extend the vocabulary and define an IANA registry for that.  But leave other forms of extension open in a way that would require a fresh RFC to define.

I would suggest that the vocabulary registry operate on a fairly strict regime, not because of a scarcity of space, but to signal that we think that new categories should be discouraged generally.  We can't completely cut that off: experience with registries shows that if you are too strict, people don't bother with registration, instead they just use whatever codepoints they like without any coordination.  Such things lead to interoperability failure and can make things very unhealthy.  I'd probably suggest that we pick one of the [RFC 8126](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8126#section-4) options that looks permissive, but add instructions that strongly discourage registration in practice.  I like [Specification Required](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8126#section-4.6) for that sort of thing.

comments.author: lrosenthol
comments.body: +1 to @martinthomson - sounds like a good direction

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Discussed at the design team meeting and our direction there was to remove the registry.  We concluded there to insist on a new RFC for any extensions, rather than to open this up.  That's unlike other protocol registries, but we accepted the risks there.

issues.title: Is inference a sub-category of TDM?
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
I had assumed that TDM would be very broad, @paul2keller [did not](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/pull/39#issuecomment-2943398120):

> I am not so sure we should treat the inference category as a proper subset of the TDM category. This is something I am somewhat skeptical of, i think there are probably inference type uses that are not necessarily TDM.

This is an interesting question that we should resolve.  If nothing else, we say that TDM is a broad category that encompasses all the other categories, so if it doesn't encompass inference, we need to fix the document one way or other (#39 for encompassing, something else if not).

comments.author: lrosenthol
comments.body:
Agreed we need to resolve this.

I, for one, would favor it being part of TDM

comments.author: paul2keller
comments.body: @lrosenthol I don't think our decision should come down to our preferences. I think if we want to include it in TDM we would need to be certain that all forms of inference meet the definition of TDM. And I have doubts (mainly because if feel that many situations where individual users feed an asset to an AI system may have more to do with concepts like making private copies or touch on issues like freedom of expression). I do not see these types of conflicts when it comes to training mostly because training is something that will usually not be done by private individuals

comments.author: lrosenthol
comments.body:
The 'M' in TDM is "mining" - in that a system is "deriving information from machine-read material".

Since the use cases that we currently define as part of "inference" - e.g., style reference, RAG, etc. - all do exactly that, I don't see how it would not fit under TDM.

comments.author: IJustWantAJob
comments.body:
I don't think inference is a sub-section of TDM.

This is a definition of TDM I found online:
"Text and Data Mining (TDM) is the process of deriving information from machine-read material. It works by copying large quantities of material, extracting the data, and recombining it to identify patterns."

By contrast inference (including style reference and RAG) just applies the pretrained model to new (typically user sourced) inputs. Since inference does not scan the data to extract patterns/insights, it should not be a sub-section of TDM or under the same umbrella

comments.author: saiful148
comments.body:
> I had assumed that TDM would be very broad, [@paul2keller](https://github.com/paul2keller) [did not](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/pull/39#issuecomment-2943398120):
> 
> > I am not so sure we should treat the inference category as a proper subset of the TDM category. This is something I am somewhat skeptical of, i think there are probably inference type uses that are not necessarily TDM.
> 
> This is an interesting question that we should resolve. If nothing else, we say that TDM is a broad category that encompasses all the other categories, so if it doesn't encompass inference, we need to fix the document one way or other ([#39](https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/pull/39) for encompassing, something else if not).

comments.author: paul2keller
comments.body: I believe we can close this based in the edits that we have made to the draft to reflect the discussions at the London design team meeting

issues.title: Is search a sub-category of TDM?
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body: And how does it relate to the other usage categories?

comments.author: felixreda
comments.body:
It is worth pointing out an inconsistency regarding the relationship between categories. As they are currently defined in the latest draft, the search and inference categories overlap. Yet, in the overview of categories at the top of the vocabulary definition section, they are shown as mutually exclusive. 

Search:
> The act of using one or more assets to build a search index **or as input to a trained AI/ML model that has the purpose of providing search results** that include direct links to the location from where the asset was obtained.

Inference:
> The act of using one or more assets **as input to a trained AI/ML model as part of the operation of that model** (as opposed to the training of the model).

comments.author: paul2keller
comments.body: yes we are aware of this and I agree that this needs to be addressed (my preference would be by narrowing down the search category)

comments.author: paul2keller
comments.body: I believe we can close this based in the edits that we have made to the draft to reflect the discussions at the London design team meeting

issues.title: robots.txt syntax
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
There's a discussion on-list about how to spell the inclusion of preferences in robots.txt.  Several considerations are in play:

* How do preferences and crawling interact?  Do preferences apply separate from crawling or do they only apply to resources where crawling is permitted?
* How do we manage backwards compatibility?  In particular, what changes in parsers that do not understand any newly-added stuff?
* What syntax do we align with?  The HTTP field definition or the Allow/Disallow pattern that robots.txt already uses?
* What, if any, extensibility is needed?

The current draft includes one proposal.  That presupposes one set of answers to these questions, but we need to discuss whether these answers are the best ones.

issues.title: People deliberately overriding/ignoring preferences
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
In discussion, we've had a number of points where people raised concerns about (for example) inference where a person provides content to a model that has inference=n attached to it.  In that case, it distinguishes itself from RAG because the person is taking responsibility for overriding the preference; whereas a model that goes off and fetches content for grounding (or whatever you call it) might be obligated to respect preferences.

We need to acknowledge that there are cases where people can take responsibility for ignoring preferences, but other settings in which systems might respect them.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: The bulk of this discussion is continuing on #2.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: This has been addressed in #92.  At least a first version of it.

issues.title: Make clear the distinction between acquisition and use
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
We don't say anything about this distinction, but it is an important one.

robots.txt `Allow` and `Disallow` rules define what can and cannot be obtained by a crawler.

The rules that we are adding will define what preferences attach to content/assets that are obtained.

That is, content that can be crawled will gain preferences according to the newly-added rules.  This does not change what can (or cannot) be acquired.

comments.author: llemeurfr
comments.body:
So, Disallow means no access -> not even conventional search. `Allow` means, by default, any type of access. I struggle to see which content provider would allow access to their content BUT explicitly opt-out from conventional search (while saying `yes` to some other TDM-related use of their content). 

The Search category, in the current vocabulary draft, does not make any difference between conventional search and "AI Search" / "AI Overview".  I think that the vocabulary must focus on the latter and let the traditional `Disallow` deal with conventional search.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
> I struggle to see which content provider would allow access to their content BUT explicitly opt-out from conventional search

At this stage, I don't think that we need to make assumptions about what people might or might not choose to do.  Certainly, it seems like "search" is the most benign and beneficial of potential TDM categories, but there are two things I generally hold to be true: your imagination is rarely good enough to anticipate future developments and people are weird.  If we don't need to constrain things in a particular way -- that is, the constraint doesn't deliver some benefit -- then why would we.

> The Search category, in the current vocabulary draft, does not make any difference between conventional search and "AI Search" / "AI Overview".

That's probably best directed to the discussion on the list and #1.  I think that this is entirely deliberate: we decided to look at the outcome of the application, not so much how it is implemented.  As our friends in search are happy to remind us: search _is_ an AI application, so attempting to distinguish between "search" and "AI search" is essentially meaningless.  By keeping focus on the effect of the application, and by asking "is the link to the content the focus?", we avoid having to engage with the minutiae of how the application is built.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Something that came up at the design team meeting: we might want to articulate the point that some crawlers will choose not to crawl assets if the preferences associated with those assets restrict the uses that the crawlers serve.  For instance, if a crawler is gathering assets for training AI and the preference is `ai=n`, the crawler might choose not to crawl the annotated assets.

issues.title: Explain what no preference means
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
This is the situation today: no preferences are attached[^1].  So, when there is no explicit preference signal, explain that it means just that: no preference signal .

[^1]: There are some existing preference signaling systems, but they don't use our vocabulary.  Yet.

issues.title: Is ASCII normative or informative?
issues.author: TimidRobot
issues.body:
# Issue

The `ASCII` reference is defined inline multiple conflicting times:
1. Normative:
   https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/blob/a0f9979749a89c548bbee1ef5ebc742556baf19f/draft-ietf-aipref-vocab.md?plain=1#L253
2. Informative:
   https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/blob/a0f9979749a89c548bbee1ef5ebc742556baf19f/draft-ietf-aipref-vocab.md?plain=1#L272
   https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/blob/a0f9979749a89c548bbee1ef5ebc742556baf19f/draft-ietf-aipref-vocab.md?plain=1#L466


# Proposed solution

1. Move `ASCII` reference to the header
   - This will remove the need to define it inline, with each occurrence risking conflict with the others
3. Make it normative
   - As there is a normative reference, it must be listed as normative


# Related
- [IESG Statement: Normative and Informative References](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/statement-iesg-iesg-statement-normative-and-informative-references-20060419/)
- [kramdown-rfc README.md](https://github.com/cabo/kramdown-rfc/blob/92337e5af1371d482f1a1fe2b1fcea109c873658/README.md):
  > By indicating a normative reference as in `{{!RFC2119}}` or an informative one as in `{{?RFC1925}}`, you can
completely automate the referencing, without the need to write anything in the header.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
Having normative and informative references inline is a feature that I'm exploiting, not a bug.

If you look at the examples, there are both normative and informative uses.  The kramdown-rfc tool looks at this and upgrades the reference to be normative if there are normative uses.  That's what happens here.

The reason to have both is that -- should the normative usage be removed in the course of editing -- you don't need to do anything to have the citation moved to the informative section.  If you move it to the header, then that is extra work to do.  (We do that work anyway in the final review of the document, but it's easier to handle if the setup is correct from the outset.)

issues.title: Tighten requirements for new categories of use
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body: The discussion in the design team leads to the conclusion that Specification Required is entirely too permissive a policy.  Consider tightening that up.  A lot.  This might extend to removing the registry entirely, so that the only way of extending is to write a new RFC that updates the vocabulary RFC.

issues.title: Clarify scope of combination
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
At the design team meeting we concluded that all three of our imagined attachment methods are co-equal and that the least permissive option rules.  We should say that other types of attachment (we discussed content preference registries) are not covered by this as those have very different rules.

As a side note: we discussed not including anything about the way in which multiple copies of the same content might lead to different preferences.  The natural conclusion there is that this is OK (some of that content can be used, some cannot), but we wouldn't say anything in the core documents.  That is something that is worth noting in some supplemental material that explains the specifications more expansively.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: The text already says "absent other guidance", which I think is sufficient in this case.

issues.title: Add "train" to "ai" and "genai" labels
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body: We are constantly tripping up over the notion that "ai" refers to AI usage more broadly.  This is OK in the English-language names for these categories of use, but it might pay to make the short labels clearer, even if that makes them much longer.  That clarity might be more important than brevity in this case.

comments.author: paul2keller
comments.body: closed via #82

issues.title: Clarify in Attachment that machine-readable preference statements do not override contracts
issues.author: sposth

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: I believe that this is adequately addressed by the dependency that the attachment document has on the vocabulary.  The attachment draft only provides a way to associate a machine-readable statement of preferences with an asset.  How the model is interpreted (the "cannot override" statement) belongs in the definition of that model.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: There's new text for this in #92 that I think should do, at least for the moment.  We can look at refining that in subsequent changes.

issues.title: Add Registry-based Preferences
issues.author: sposth
issues.body:
Suggested changes to the heading and the first paragraph of '1.3.  Embedded Preferences':

1) Change Heading

"1.3.  Embedded Preferences"
-->
"1.3. Embedded and Registry-Based Preferences" 

2) Change first paragraph

"This document does not define a means of embedding preferences in content. Embedding preferences is expected to be an effective means of associating preferences with content, because it ensures that metadata is always associated with content."

-->

"This document does not define a means of embedding preferences in content **or associating them via content-derived identifiers such as ISCC (ISO 24138:2024). Both embedded preferences and registry-based approaches using content-derived fingerprints are** expected to be an effective means of associating preferences with content, because *they* ensure that metadata is always associated with content."

(Changes in bold)

@martinthomson

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Personally, I don't agree with the assertion that these are equivalently effective means of attachment.  There's a very big difference between these methods of attachment.  I will raise this on the mailing list, but I personally don't think that this is the right way to manage mention of alternative attachment mechanisms (including registries).

comments.author: hardie
comments.body:
I would suggest making this a separate  entry, with text like:

This document does not define a means of associating preferences them via content-derived identifiers such as ISCC (ISO 24138:2024). Registry-based approaches using content-derived fingerprints may be common in certain contexts, and we expect future work to define these means.

comments.author: sposth
comments.body:
Thanks @martinthomson and @hardie 

I agree with your comments and would like to suggest a version based on the previous comment that distinguishes the Registry-based Attachment from Embedding.

"1.4. Registry-Based Preferences

This document does not define a means of associating preferences via content-derived identifiers such as ISCC (ISO 24138:2024) and providing them through public registries. Registry-based approaches using content-derived fingerprints may be applicable in certain contexts, particularly where embedding is impractical or unavailable. Such mechanisms may enable persistent association of preferences across distribution channels. We anticipate that future work may define these approaches in more detail."

comments.author: wumpus
comments.body: I am not in favor of mentioning registries at all. That's an extremely different method compared to what we are creating here.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Addressed in #83.

issues.title: Alternative syntax definitions
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body: New (embedded) attachment mechanisms might wish to map a different syntax into the abstract data model we have (categories of use with y/n/? attached to each). To do that, there needs be a clear definition of the mapping from their syntax to these semantics.  That mapping might be incomplete in some ways; it might also lose information.  Either way, it needs to be unambiguous.

issues.author: lrosenthol

comments.author: martinthomson

issues.title: Can a statement of preferences really express preferences about none of the categories?
issues.author: paul2keller
issues.body:
A question for @martinthomson since I think the language originated with him. We currently have the following in the draft:

> A statement of preferences can express preferences about some, all, or none of the categories from the vocabulary. This can mean that no preference is expressed for a given usage category

How does one in practice express a preference for none of the categories of the vocabulary? Are there attachment mechanisms that allow this? Feels somewhat odd to me but I am probably not thinking this fully though.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
A concrete example might be `Content-Usage: unknown`, which is valid syntax according to RFC 9541, but it carries no statement of preference for one of the categories that the recipient knows about.  This is because we require that values are ignored if they are not understood.

This is still a statement of preferences -- in a sense -- but it carries no information.

issues.title: Is the language about stakeholder consensus still appropriate?
issues.author: paul2keller
issues.body:
We currently have the following in the draft: 

> This list of specific use cases may be expanded in the future, should a consensus emerge between stakeholders, to include categories that address additional use cases as they emerge. In addition to these categories defined in the vocabulary, it is also expected that some systems implementing this vocabulary may extend this list with additional categories for their particular needs.

Is the “should a consensus emerge between stakeholders” still an accurate description? Does not sound very IETF process compatible to me (this is a remnant of our original vocabulary proposal) and might need to be updated

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Fair.  I'll take a look at revising this.  As we discussed at the recent meeting, extensions to the vocabulary will require new IETF RFCs that update this document.

Any statement of preference based on this vocabulary shall not be interpreted as restricting the use of the work(s) strictly for the purpose of search and discovery as long as no restriction is declared through search-specific means such as {{!RFC9309}}.

issues.title: The Search carve-out -> all applications defining themselves as "Search"
issues.author: mjoras
issues.body:
This is related to #98 but I think it warrants a separate discussion beyond refining the definition, since having a carve-out for one category may be problematic. It's possible this was discussed at the meetings and I'm missing some context, but it seems like carving out "Search" will have an inevitable effect of applications contorting themselves to be Search-oriented for the likely outcome of more permissive preferences.

For example, suppose a content owner does not want to be de-listed from all modern search the utilizes AI for the "core search" technology. They do not however want to consent to say, a chatbot-like application which is going to perform a "deep research" style feature that produces an extended report with a citation to the source. The existing definition carve out simply says:

> Using one or more assets in a search application that directs users to the location from which the assets were retrieved.

It is pretty easy to suggest any linking to the original content "directs the user to the location". This can go beyond text too, for example, suppose a hypothetical product which produces a short form video or podcast based on a research topic. As part of the media output, it produces URLs linking to the source material. The application can claim this is "directing the user to that location".

I'm not sure there's any viable way around this beyond getting more specific about the particular application experiences, or, alternatively, not having carve-outs at all. If the former, there likely needs to be more specific taxonomy for application use cases, that likely evolve over time.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: To the extent that the application meets the definition, that might be fair game.  Where things get hairy is where multiple uses are combined into the same interface.  I don't think that it makes sense to regard the application as search if that is just a component of the whole.

comments.author: mjoras
comments.body: @martinthomson do you agree that this leads to a natural incentive of "compliance" contortions into "Search"? If the definition is sufficiently easy to meet from an application experience point of view (providing URLs), all applications will do the bare minimum to meet the definition.

comments.author: mnot
comments.body: @mjoras please raise issues on the list, not here.

issues.title: Are AI overviews "search"?

issues.title: Should the path in `Content-Usage` of Robots.txt be part of a structured field?
issues.author: lrosenthol
issues.body:
Currently the path part of `Content-Usage` is separate from the rest of the value, and thus requires MULTIPLE parsers to handle the value of content usage - one to split the string between path (if present), one to process the path (if present) according to an *undefined methodology* and then a structured fields parser for the prefs part.

I would suggest that the entire value of `Content-Usage` be a proper structured field value enabling a single parser.  Doing so would mean a few extra bytes, such as `path=` or if we were trying to reduce byte count, then `p=`.

Also, since we're using its as a term of art, we might want to include it in terminology.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: @paul2keller and I discussed and we agree that this is about each discrete statement made (in robots.txt).  I would say that post-combination it is a "combined set of statements of preference" as necessary.

pulls.title: Move to standards track
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
In looking through the draft and the scope of this work item, it seems like this work is going to have to define something concrete.  That is, any attachment draft (which will be a protocol for real) will need to normatively reference this document in order for it to make sense.  In that spirit, I think that we need this to be a standards-track document, not an informational document.

Changing the intended status here will make all that possible.

pulls.title: First cut at removing the opt-out language
pulls.author: martinthomson

This document proposes a standardized vocabulary for expressing preferences related to how digital assets are used by automated processing systems.

pulls.title: The abstract model
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
There are a few things here that I'm struggling with, but I'm starting with the basics.

The first is to better define the abstract model.  That is, each category of use has a preference that is either "allow", "disallow", or "unstated".

The next is to give us more space for category definitions.  Right now, these are pretty short, but we'll need to say more.  I've not modified text much, but I've added notes about AI and GenAI being subsets of the preceding categories.

There is also new text on what it means to receive more specific instructions.  The old text was not clear about the ways in which things might be made more specific.  I've expanded this to note the two ways:

1. that the vocabulary might be expanded
2. there might be more specific instructions in agreements between users of assets and other actors that override any general statement that is made

This latter point seems to be a continual point of confusion in discussions thus far, so I'm not claiming that this addresses those concerns yet.  Still, it seemed necessary to get at least a basic statement in place.

I've moved a few things around as well, to get things into a better flow.  In preparation for adding more text on exemplary serialization, search, inference, and other such things.

pulls.title: Define an exemplary format
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
As discussed, we want to define a recommended format.  This executes on that.  It uses Structured Fields, which will ensure that we have a very easy translation to HTTP fields.  It also fits neatly into the other formats we are considering.

There are some interesting implications that are worth highlighting. The text I've added goes into some of that in more detail, but just to list them for visibility:

* This is a sequence of bytes, not a string.  That has implications for how it is included in some formats, but as RFC 9651 limits its syntax to a pretty small subset of the ASCII range, this is mostly just a theoretical consideration, not a practical one.

* Parsing errors in RFC 9651 means that you lose everything.  No preference survives.  That means that authoring errors have consequences.  This is an artifact of the format being more of a computer-to-computer language, rather than being tolerant of human error.  I'm not thrilled with this, but recognize the trade-off involved.

* Repeated keys mean that only the last one is taken.  Again, not thrilled with this, but think that the trade is tolerable.

* Labels are lowercase only.  A lot of the list traffic has started to use "AI=whatever"; RFC 9651 doesn't let us shout.  I think that this is fine, but it's another minor ding.

* Some patterns of use that might be natural are invalid.  For instance, spaces around the "=" is invalid, so "ai = n" would result in a parsing error and no preference being registered.

Closes #8.

pulls.title: Removed reference to origin of TDM definition
pulls.author: paul2keller
pulls.body:
This pull request proposes to leave the definition of TDM unchanged, but removes the explicit reference that this is based on EU law. This is part based on a review of existing legal definitions of TDM in other jurisdictions that have TDM exceptions in ether copyright law: 

The UK does not have a proper definition in the law itself, but the UK government provides on as part of its Guidance on Exceptions to copyright which is very similar to the EU definition: 

"Text and data mining is the use of automated analytical techniques to analyse text and data for patterns, trends and other useful information."

The other two jurisdictions with TDM exceptions that I am aware of (Singapore and Japan) do not use the term TDM. Instead they anchor the exceptions on “computational data analysis” (SG) or “data analysis (JP). 

Given this it seems sensible to keep the definition of TDM as unchanged.

comments.author: paul2keller
comments.body:
Background and links to the relevant passages the copyright legislation of the above mentioned jurisdictions: 

### 🇪🇺 European Union:

In the EU the definition is laid down [in Article 2(2) of the Copyright in the Digital Single Market Directive](https://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/dir/2019/790/oj/eng#art_2):

> ‘text and data mining’ means any automated analytical technique aimed at analysing text and data in digital form in order to generate information which includes but is not limited to patterns, trends and correlations.
> 

### 🇬🇧 United Kingdom

The UK does not have a proper defintion in the law, but the UK government provides on as part of its [Guidance on Exceptions to copyright](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/exceptions-to-copyright):

> Text and data mining is the use of automated analytical techniques to analyse text and data for patterns, trends and other useful information.
> 

The [actual TDM exception in UK law](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1988/48/section/29A) specifies that it is not an infringement of copyright to "carry out a computational analysis of anything recorded in the work”

### 🇸🇬 Singapore (computational data analysis)

Singapore does not have a definition of TDM instead it defines the equivalent term “Computational data analysis” [in section 244 of its copyright code](https://sso.agc.gov.sg/Act/P15-P28-):

> “computational data analysis”, in relation to a work or a recording of a protected performance, includes 
(a)	using a computer program to identify, extract and analyse information or data from the work or recording; and
(b)	using the work or recording as an example of a type of information or data to improve the functioning of a computer program in relation to that type of information or data.
> 

### 🇯🇵 Japan (data analysis)

Japan does not have an explicit definition. [Here is the relevant text in Article 30-4](https://www.cric.or.jp/english/clj/cl2.html) is referred to as the Japanese TDM exception (emphasis mine):

> It is permissible to exploit a work, in any way and to the extent considered necessary, in any of the following cases, or in any other case in which it is not a person's purpose to personally enjoy or cause another person to enjoy the thoughts or sentiments expressed in that work; provided, however, that this does not apply if the action would unreasonably prejudice the interests of the copyright owner in light of the nature or purpose of the work or the circumstances of its exploitation:
> 
> 
> (i)　if it is done for use in testing to develop or put into practical use technology that is connected with the recording of sounds or visuals of a work or other such exploitation;
> 
> (ii)　**if it is done for use in data analysis (meaning the extraction, comparison, classification, or other statistical analysis of the constituent language, sounds, images, or other elemental data from a large number of works or a large volume of other such data**; the same applies in Article 47-5, paragraph (1), item (ii));

pulls.title: Add a description of how the model is interrogated
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
This is stacked on top of #26.  It just shows the incremental change.  (If it is accepted and #26 is not, we'll lose it.  Be careful.)

Rather than describe how defaults apply as part of the processing algorithm, I've made that part of how the model is consulted.  This doesn't have any functional impact in this case; the result is the same either way.

The main decision this makes is about the order in which things apply:

1. within a single statement, the most-specific statement applies (i.e., `genai` overrides `ai`)
2. across multiple statements, the least-permissive statement of preference applies (i.e., `n` overrides `y`)

We'll need to discuss which model we want to follow and be deliberate about it.

An example should help.  Consider two statements of preference that include no preference for nested categories: `ai=n` and `genai=y`.

In the proposed approach, the more general answer from the first statement fills in an answer for the `genai` category.  That's the model that this change adopts.  The final, combined answer for `genai` is determined by the `ai=n` preference because the value from that statement is taken first and a disallow preference overrides an allow preference (absent other information; see the text).

In an alternative model, preferences could be combined before resolving any inherited preferences.  That is, items 1 and 2 above are swapped to:

1. across multiple statements, the least permissive statement of preference for each category is selected
2. then any category without an assigned preference inherits the preference of any less-specific category

In that case, we'd be saying that `ai=n` leaves `genai` unspecified deliberately to allow another preference to set `genai=y` if they prefer.  Only if no other entity expresses a preference, does the implied `genai=n` apply.  In that model, we'd be assuming that the entity that sets `ai=n` knows about `genai` and chooses to defer to others on what the preference is.

I personally dislike the alternative.  It makes any vocabulary extension fraught with issues.  Consider that an extension we define later might carve out space for a new specialized usage (like `inference`, if we were to define that in three years time, or `commercial` or anything else we might defer).  That would put an unexpected hole in any established preference.  Anyone who previously said no to a class of usage could have that preference overridden for that specialized usage.

Structuring the document this way allows us to make a decision between these a little more easily than if the "processing" in #26 filled in values for `genai` from the value of `ai`.

Finally, the last decision in the change is that attachment mechanisms can define that one statement can override another.

That opens the possibility of us choosing to have the HTTP header override robots.txt or even having content metadata override any other preferences.  If we find that this isn't needed, that's fine, but I understand that this is still on the table.  Including it cost me little effort; removing it would be equally easy.

pulls.title: Revise intent statement

This is a version of the text provided by Timid Robot in https://github.com/ietf-wg-aipref/drafts/pull/31#discussion_r2100758813 with some additional edits, particularly the last sentence, where I think we need to be clear that:

1. This shouldn't prejudice decisions about other rights outside of the meaning of the preference itself.
2. The no prejudice piece applies even if the preferencing has legal effect, outside of the direct and obvious legal effect itself.
3. This isn't necessarily exclusively about copyright.  People have privacy rights over content that still apply, even if the preferences admit the possibility of use.

I think that this maintains the intent of the original, but I will admit that the original is dense enough that I might have lost some of the intent.

pulls.title: IANA registry
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
(Again, this is based on #26; merge this and nothing happens unless you also merge #26.)

This enacts the suggested approach for vocabulary extensions I described in #38.

Still, this was particularly tricky to get the wording even remotely in the space I wanted and I'm not sure whether I got there.  Input on this would be appreciated.

Basically, I'm conflicted on this.  Using Specification Required gives some flexibility for the process to recognize emerging labels without a lot of procedural overhead, but it seems like this is angling toward IETF Review as the operative policy.  Should we face facts and just go straight for IETF Review?  That would allow the advice to be a little more streamlined, because we'd be able to rely on the standards process to iron out the kinks.

There's also the option to pair IETF Review with IESG Approval, which means "get an RFC" or "convince an IETF AD".  That almost amounts to the same thing in practice (if you can convince an AD of something, one of those things is publishing an RFC.  Though the RFC still requires IETF consensus, so it's a somewhat higher bar, but only "somewhat" given how careful most ADs are).

In any case, this seemed like a reasonable starting point for a discussion, which is always easier when there is something concrete to discuss.

pulls.title: Update acknowledgments
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
The IETF policy is that people participate as individuals, which means that we do not generally list affiliation when it comes to acknowledgments.  There's a carve-out for authorship and a few other things, but this is how we generally operate.

The formatting ensures that people can use their actual name.  Not a problem for these all-ASCII names, but it might end up being a problem later.

I've also sorted the list (by first name, which is my preferred approach once we have to deal with people who put family names first and all that).

There are probably a few other people that we might add here, though I want to be clear about the level of contribution before doing that. Both Brad and Felix have been very helpful on-list lately.

pulls.title: A reframing of search
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
As discussed on the list recently.

This does not include Brad's suggestion of "for the exclusive purpose of".  That is an important clarification, but I think we need to address that separately.  That is, we need to recognize that what we conceive of as "search" applications are more complicated than a simple index that is used to locate stuff.  We need commentary that explains that a single application can embody multiple usage categories and that use of assets for each of those aspects can have separate rules.  This isn't necessarily how those applications are built today[^1], but that's not necessarily a constraint on what we do.

[^1]: I am reminded of the concept of a "data lake", which has no distinction about where data has come from, the purpose for which it was obtained, or anything along those lines, making compliance with data protection regulation impossible.  The analogy here is with respect to use of assets for multiple purposes, without distinction.  For data lakes, the introduction of things like GDPR helped application developers build discipline about how they obtain and label personal information; perhaps this requires a similar shift, albeit one that affects a smaller set of people.

pulls.title: robots.txt attachment: make path segment mandatory
pulls.author: bnewbold
pulls.body:
This updates the draft text to make the path segment mandatory instead of optional. The motivation is to make the `Content-Usage` directive read more clearly like the `Allow`/`Disallow` directives, and generally make robots.txt files more legible and understandable to humans (whether they have prior experience with robots.txt or not). This should have almost no impact on actual behavior or what preferences can be expressed. The trade-off is that every line will have two additional bytes for the case of "all paths", and that seems like a reasonable trade off for legibility.

A secondary benefit is that implementation becomes marginally easier: code will know there is always a leading path segment. While optional fields are common in protocols, it is more common to have trailing fields be optional, not leading fields. The current text *is* unambiguous about how to detect whether there is a path segment or not (if there is a leading `/` character), but this makes things just a bit easier to implement correctly.

I think this would be an improvement on the syntax and it would be great to get it in. However, I do want to prioritize moving work forward, and think this improvement is not worth holding things up.

comments.author: bnewbold
comments.body: To expand on thinking of this a bit more: I suspect if the path is optional, it will be common to not include it, and set overall preferences for entire websites, perhaps by group (eg, by named crawler). If that is a common pattern, it is possible for developers, hosts, and crawlers to never encounter a line with a path segment, and make incorrect assumptions about allowed syntax.

pulls.title: A more verbose search definition
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
This keeps the short definition, but it expands it considerably to cover what seems to be the emerging perspective on the list.

This aims to do three things:

1. Narrow the definition to cover those cases that drive traffic to the original location of assets.

2. Ensure that this allows the use of AI in search applications, so that search preferences override AI use preferences.

3. To ensure that AI overviews, which act as a substitute for visiting the site, are excluded.

Obviously, there will continue to be things on the line.  The draft has text addressing the question of ambiguity.  As has been noted, the law has far better tools for managing that than technical specifications... if there is a dispute, that is.

comments.body:
```suggestion
This includes the use of titles or excerpts from assets
that are used to help users select between multiple candidate options.

Preferences for the Search category apply to those parts of applications
that provide search capabilities,
regardless of what other preferences are expressed.
```

```suggestion
Search applications can be complex 
and may serve multiple purposes.
```

```suggestion
Only those parts of applications that direct users to the location of an asset
are included in this category of use.
```

pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
This is a light reworking of a proposal from Lila Bailey on the list.

The value of this is that it is far more comprehensive than the previous text, which was directionally helpful, but not thorough enough to give the right impression.  Having more text is often something to avoid, but in this case it seems like it is adding a lot of value in terms of making the *preferences* thing far clearer.

My only concern here -- which is a very minor one -- is that this looks almost exclusively at the overriding of preferences to disallow.  I couldn't come up with a convincing example of a decision to ignore express permission.

Closes #99.

pulls.title: Define AI and AI Training
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
This is a less hurried version of what I threw together during the sessions on Monday morning of the IETF meeting.

This draws on many definitions, primarily the one from Luciano Floridi in his commentary about the discussions between the EU and US: https://doi.org/10.1007/s13347-023-00690-z

That document includes a number of citations to legal definitions and other definitional work, including by the OECD, that were influential in coming to a definition.  I found a number of other sources, including the ITU definition mentioned in #100 (thanks to @taddhar for sharing that).

The definitions of AI Training and Machine Learning are a synthesis of much longer definitions by c3.ai and IBM, primarily. https://c3.ai/glossary/data-science/model-training/ https://www.ibm.com/think/topics/machine-learning

Closes #100.
