comments.author: paul2keller
comments.body:
I think we are at risk of loosing substantial safeguards here.We need to have explicit language that there will be situations in which legal regimes override any preferences (the most concrete example, although not the best because Eurocentrism concerns) is the TDM exception for scientific research in Article 3 the EU copyright directive. 

I think the approach to combine (or at least move closer to each other) the legal section and this one makes a lot of sense. And as a reminder there is one other section in the doc that also deals with this issue, that is the 2nd para of the `#introduction` section:

> The vocabulary is intended to be used in jurisdictions where expressing preferences results in legal obligations, as well as where there are no associated legal obligations. In either case, expressing preferences is without prejudice to applicable laws, including the applicability of exceptions and limitations to copyright.

I propose that, to the extent these changes are incorporated, "an unconditional right" be revised to "a right"  and "never" be changed to "not".  For the same reason,  I suggest, throughout the text of the spec and document, to change the words "respect" and "ignored" to "followed" and "not followed."  Plus, as the tech spec and documents are directed at technology, not people,  "respect" and "ignored" are anthropomorphic.

comments.body: Closing in favour of #118.

```suggestion
## Enforcement

This specification does not provide any enforcement mechanism,
and conformance to it does not encompass whether
preferences are actually respected during data processing.

Other mechanisms
-- technical, legal, or otherwise --
might enforce stated preferences.
As such they will determine the consequences for ignoring a stated preference.
Preferences do not imply control, either in the positive or negative.
For example, a stated preference allowing a use does not
(on its own) imply an unconditional right to use it for that purpose;
likewise, a stated preference disallowing a use does not
(on its own) mean that the content can never be used for that purpose.
```

yes this is tricky. for me there are two aspects where I would consider this to preserve important elements of the original language we had before attempts to merge the two sections: 

1. the very unambiguous `MAY` in "A data processor MAY choose to respect preferences that is has discovered" that for me is a very important signal that we are talking about "preferences" that in itself do not have legal effect, and

reviews.author: martinthomson
reviews.body: This is turning out to be a difficult needle to successfully thread.  As with other genuine attempts to improve the text, this is helpful.  I just don't know what razor to apply to decide which is best.

comments.body:
```suggestion
Because enforcement is not provided by this specification,
the consequences of ignoring preferences may vary
depending upon how a given legal jurisdiction recognizes preferences;
see {{applicability}}.
```

A list of two might just be better as a sentence:

```suggestion
discovered, according to
an understanding of how the asset is used,
how that usage corresponds to the usage categories
where preferences have been expressed,
and the applicable legal context.
```
I think that I prefer Mark's take on this list of things, both the framing and the "might be allowed by a legal system to ignore a preference" language.

you mean replacing lines 198 and 199 with: 

> For example, a legal system might require adherence to stated preferences,
but allow them to be ignored for specified purposes, such as:
And probably the other tweaks made to each of the list items.  I know it's almost redundant, but I've learned that spending the extra words on being extra precise is often necessary.

I prefer @paul2keller s proposed language insofar as it doesn't refer to a legal system that allows ignoring a certain preference. By default, anything that is not expressly prohibited by a legal system is allowed. Therefore, a legal system rarely is explicit in what it allows. Consequently, "a legal system might ... allow them to be ignored" could create misunderstandings where people might read this as requiring an explicit legal provision that allows somebody to ignore a stated preference. In reality, unless a legal system explicitly requires somebody to _respect_ a stated preference, ignoring it is allowed.
